sub_title: Award Winning Science Communicator | TOPX Network for Women in Life Sciences Junior Ambassador | PhD Candidate | Marketing Associate at BioLizard 🦎
summary: I am an award-winning science communicator, an enthusiastic speaker and event moderator, a PhD candidate, and Marketing Associate at BioLizard. My missions are to improve public understanding of science and to support women in science. Alongside my doctoral research (which focuses on the role of autophagy - the recycling system of our cells - in protecting humans from viruses), I am active in the worlds of science communication and empowering women in science. As the writer and creator of "Microbial Mondays", a blog that aims to improve public understanding of microbiology, I have published over a hundred articles and award-winning short videos that explain biological concepts in jargon-free language. I am also a junior ambassador for TOPX, a network and training platform for ambitious women in Life Sciences, where my tasks include speaking and moderating at live and online events, and writing career articles relevant for the TOPX community of women in science.

treasury_media.title: Winner of FameLab Netherlands 2021
treasury_media.description: I was the winner of the Dutch National FameLab contest in 2021, with my talk, "How to Declutter Your Viruses". FameLab is a science communication competition that aims to discover charismatic, up-and-coming scientists who inspire people to see the world from a new perspective… in just three minutes!

treasury_media.title: 'The Virus'.
treasury_media.description: I guess you can all guess what this one is about. Up until this point, I've been cautious - perhaps overly cautious, as scientists are wont to be - about writing a Microbial Mondays post about the SARS-Coronavirus-2 (or SARS-CoV-2 for short), the...

education.field_of_study: Psychology and Biology (double major, with Honours in Biology)

profile_positions.description: I post weekly on my website, with the goal of improving public understanding of microbiology.
profile_positions.title: Creator & Writer

profile_positions.description: The TOPX Network supports personal and professional development of women in Life Sciences, and offers training in leadership, management, entrepreneurship, and other key topics in life sciences and academia. TOPX ambassador roles include assisting with organization and execution of TOPX events, advising on the TOPX programme and services, and attending and promoting TOPX events.
profile_positions.title: TOPX Network Junior Ambassador

profile_positions.description: I teach vinyasa yoga: the perfect yoga style for students and other busy people alike! It is a type of yoga that will leave you both relaxed and energized, ready to face the rest of your day. Vinyasa helps you accomplish this by working your body through an energetic, creative sequence of yoga poses (asanas) coordinated with the flow of your breath. By moving your body and breath through these poses, and with the help of a short meditation at the end of practice, you will leave the class with your mind relaxed, and your body energized and exercised.
profile_positions.title: Yoga Instructor

profile_positions.description:
Supervisor: Dr. François Jean, UBC Infection, Inflammation & Immunity Research Group
Topic: Flaviviral hijacking of lipid droplets
profile_positions.title: Research Intern

profile_positions.description:
Group: Host Defense (Prof. Dr. Geijtenbeek), Department of Experimental Immunology 
Daily supervisor: Dr. Carla Ribeiro
Topic: Role of autophagy in virus-induced inflammation
Key skills: Human cell culture and ex vivo explant model; work in ML-3 lab (Dengue and HIV); RNA interference; autophagosome isolation; flow cytometry.

Based on preliminary data generated in this internship, I wrote a PhD project proposal and in June 2018 was awarded an AMC PhD Scholarship (€216 064) to continue my into a PhD.
profile_positions.title: Research Intern

profile_positions.description: Research Intern in computational immunology at the Laboratory of Translational Immunology, University Medical Centre Utrecht.
profile_positions.title: Research Intern

profile_positions.description:
I worked in the Medical Microbiology Department in the group of Jos van Strijp, with daily supervision from Ilse Jongerius. My research was on immune evasion molecules of Bordetella pertussis.

I gave an oral presention on my at the 2018 International Student Congress Of (bio)Medical Sciences in Groningen and was awarded Session Winner in the Public Health Category.

I was also awarded the 2018 Talma Eykman Prize (€ 1000) for this work. The Talma Eykman Prize is awarded annually to a master student in Medicine, Biomedical Sciences or Clinical Health Sciences at UMC Utrecht who has written an excellent research report or literature thesis.

My work was inluded in a published manuscript, linked below.
profile_positions.title: Research Intern

profile_positions.description:
I was the Chair of the 2017 Infection & Immunity Masters Symposium: Global Health Politicized. I worked with a group of 5 other students to organise the two-day Symposium. As the chair, it was my responsibility to oversee all components of the Symposium and ensure that its preparation and implementation functioned smoothly overall.

The goal of the 2017 I&I Symposium was to present and engage students with contemporary issues in science and society. In today's globalised context, infection and immunity students must grapple with both "hard science" as well as its political and social impacts. We aim to focus on this crossroad between science and society, to prepare future scientists for modern science.
profile_positions.title: Chair, 2017 Infection & Immunity Masters Symposium

profile_positions.description: Planning and executing mock United Nations meetings and workshops to teach delegates relevant skills, such public speaking, lobbying, and researching.
profile_positions.title: Delegate Trainer

profile_positions.description:
I worked at the UBC School of Nursing, on a research project focused on analysing diabetes and obesity trends in Indigenous populations.

Tasks included drafting and editing research-related documents, screening and analyzing research papers for a systematic literature review, assisting with preparing reports to be shared with members of the research team and participating agencies, and participating with group analyses of data. Responsibilities include assisting with research planning and ensuring respect of protocols while working with local Aboriginal communities and First Nations to inform them of the study.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: This job involves living in a residence hall with first year students and creating a community that is safe, secure, conducive to academic pursuits, and conducive to students'​ personal growth and learning. As a returning residence advisor, I have the additional responsibilities of supporting new and other returning staff, and managing the UBC Okanagan Healthy Living Integrated Learning Community. Other responsibilities included knowing every student on my floor (a total of 43); being present and regularly visible to residents throughout the academic year; proposing, implementing, and evaluating a wide variety of programs (specifically those related to all areas of healthy living) for students; upholding the university's behavioural standards and regulations; providing assistance with administrative matters in residence; and leading by example.
profile_positions.title: Returning Residence Advisor

profile_positions.description:
SL leaders plan and implement collaborative sessions for students to voluntarily attend in order to gain a deeper understanding of course material. SL leaders sit in on 100 or 200 level classes and model good note taking and study skills. This job also requires good communication with professors and other SL leaders.

From September 2013-April 2014 I was an SL leader for a first year chemistry class.
From September 2014-December 2014 and September 2015 - December 2015: I was an SL leader for a second year microbiology class. I also trained mentored the rest of the team of SL leaders, assisted in training of tutors at the UBC Math and Science Centre (MSC), and gave workshops on study skills at the university level.
January 2016 - May 2016: I assisted in the management of the SL programme, including training SL leaders and MSC tutors, scheduling SL sessions and MSC tutor's hours, giving workshops on studying and note-taking skills for university students, and assisting in data analysis.
profile_positions.title: Head Supplemental Learning Leader, Academic Resource Centre

profile_positions.description: I assisted in many different aspects of several ongoing studies at the Institute for Healthy Living. This included study recruitment, interview transcription and coding, social media management, and resource production.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant, Institute for Healthy Living and Chronic Disease Prevention
Volunteer, UBC Okanagan Health Psychology Lab

profile_positions.description: As a work study student, I assisted in all aspects of several studies at the Institute for Healthy Living. This included study recruitment, interview transcription and coding, social media management, and resource production. My work contributed to the published manuscript linked below.
profile_positions.title: Work Study Student, Institute for Healthy Living and Chronic Disease Prevention

profile_positions.description: This job involved living in a residence hall with first year students and creating a community that was safe, secure, conducive to academic pursuits, and conducive to students' personal growth and learning. Responsibilities included knowing every student on my floor (a total of 43); being present and regularly visible to residents throughout the academic year; proposing, implementing, and evaluating a wide variety of programs for students; upholding the university's behavioural standards and regulations; providing assistance with administrative matters in residence; and leading by example. During my time as a Residence Advisor, I also volunteered time with RezLead, a student leadership club on the campus run by residence advisors.
